thread.title: Labour has just forced the Government into a climbdown over Universal Credit studies

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Labour has just forced the Government into a climbdown over Universal Credit studies
text:
News Labour has just forced the Government into a climbdown over Universal Credit studies Studies which could reveal new details about the impact of Universal Credit will now be released to MPs Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
The Government has backed down over Labour demands that it release a series of reports about the operation of Universal Credit. 
Ministers had been refusing to release the studies, which looked at the introduction of the controversial new benefit system. 
But Work and Pensions Secretary David Gauke has now announced the reviews will be passed over in confidence to the Work and Pensions Select Committee before MPs break for Christmas. 
He made the concession as the House of Commons prepared to debate a Labour motion calling for their release. 
Conservative MPs have been ordered to abstain on motions proposed by opposition parties, making it likely that this motion would be approved. 
And because Labour had used a procedure known as a “humble address” to the Queen, the decision would have been binding on the Government. 
Labour previously used the same procedure to force the Government to hand over studies on the impact of Brexit on different sectors of the economy. 
This time, Ministers avoided the embarrassing prospect of being forced to hand over the studies by simply agreeing to do so. David Gauke Work and Pensions Secretary (Image: Daily Mirror) 
Mr Gauke told MPs: “In line with the motion before this House, I will provide, by the time the House rises for the Christmas recess, the reports directly to the Work and Pensions select committee.” 
He said he would consider redacting certain information, such as that which is commercially sensitive, while the documents were being handed over in exceptional circumstances and did not set a precedent. 
“Against this background, I provide the reports to the select committee on a confidential basis, and in these circumstances hope and expect that documents will not be disclosed further,” he added. 
Speaking afterwards, Labour Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Debbie Abrahams said the reports “should give greater insight into the scale of their implementation and design failures during the mismanagement of the programme”. Read More
